The Kimberley Process Civil Society  coalition is at its core a watchdog, let's say it plays an observer role in the Kimberly process, but it adds a few tasks on top of that also given that it has become quite critical of where the Kimberly process is going and what relevance its certification scheme still has.

I think a key one and that's also one that goes to the core of what the Kimberley process is doing of course is the problem of the Central African Republic, which is likely to be in the spotlight also this year because there's really a fight ongoing on the KP or on the international level of how to deal with this, to deal with the fact that the country has had an embargo  imposed on it for over 10 years now.
That has been, so it was imposed on 2013 when civil war broke out.
Between 2016 and 2019, it has been relaxed in a few phases, allowing exports from certain zones, also reducing the restrictions that the KP imposed on it.
Since then, the file has really been stuck and that coincides also with the arrival of Wagner mercenaries in the CR and with an increased Russian interest in the country.
So that made geopolitics  politics enter this already very complex file and that of course wasn't helpful.

I think an overall problem with embargoes of the Kimberley process or more generally is that if they don't come with accompanying measures or with a kind of roadmap for the long term, they never actually lead to reducing diamond production.
They lead to increased smuggling.
So the diamonds continue to be mined and they find out a way out of the country through other means.
And that's even worse if the government itself of the respective country doesn't support  the sanctions, which is today the case in the CR.
And there in the Central African Republic has taken giant proportions, this smuggling and illegality.
It's really become a gangster's paradise with massive corruption, terrorist financing, true to diamond trade, rebels that continue to interfere in diamond mines.
There's of course mercenaries now that play a role.

And all of this doesn't go away when you lift the embargo, as is now being proposed by, for instance, the KP chair that is this year, the United Arab Emirates, because these  illegal networks have become very well established in the country.
They are closely intertwined with elites.
They have really whole logistical framework set up.

You want to give the formal trades more breeding space, but by lifting the embargo, you won't do that because it's too hard to compete with these illegal networks that don't have to pay taxes and so on.

I think the big challenge, how can you give more breeding space to the formal trade gradually, I think, rather than any drastic measure that  would risk to undo the very fragile progress that has been booked over very slowly, unfortunately, over a very long time.

So it's nearly that there's always only two years in between that there's no talk of reform and this discussion  of conflict diamonds is always central.

And I think that's one of the reasons why it's become so problematic in the KP is the very strict confidentiality rules within the KP, which means that there's no transparency basically as an  observer, we're not allowed to reveal positions that governments take within KP meetings, which means that everyone can use this veto power without having to be accountable for it.
They don't even have to explain why they're against the decision.
They can just simply say no, and nobody will ever question them because it's unknown who is against or who is in favor.
So I think it's more feasible, realistic to go for more transparency within the KP.
Open up this.

And that also doesn't help because these are people that have a very specific scope of work and don't see the larger picture or the needs for international cooperation or have just come from a different background.
So I think that also didn't help and led to this change.
I think it's an evolution.

Just moving away from the KP specifically, what are the other projects that your organization is working on at the moment?
We do a lot of projects in the Democratic Republic of Congo, and they're often involved  involved in the mapping of artisanal mining sites.
So in the east of the country, we have over the past 15 years, I think, already, we have been identifying and surveying artisanal mines.
So far, we visited, I think, 3,600 of these mines already.

We do that with teams of researchers that go together with technical staff of Congolese mining services that go there with long questionnaires to collect data on many different aspects, armed interference in mines, child labor, taxes, operational issues as well.
and that allow us to draw conclusions on how conflict is related to artisanal mining, on the impact of due diligence and traceability efforts, for instance.

I think one of the key conclusions there has been that it's really a very complex relation between conflict and artisanal mining, and not as it's often portrayed, is that the war in Congo would be over access to resources that is now again being portrayed with the conflict with Rwanda as such.
It's much more complicated than that these armed groups fight over access to land, customary power,  that fight, they seek resources and sometimes mines are one of the ways to get income.
But there's many others.
And for instance, roadblocks is a key use to levy taxes and that leads to much more income for armed groups than mines.
I worked more on surveying communities that live around industrial mines to see which positive, negative impacts they associate with the presence of a mining company.
For instance, done that in Tanzania as well.
Other projects on mapping roadblocks in countries like South Sudan and Central African Republic as well.
I'm a big fan of maps, which is why it caught my attention.

The purpose of those maps, is that for your purposes, so you can keep track of where everything is happening, or is it that there are people who would be interested in being able to see where everything's going on?
These maps, we mainly make them, we invest a lot in open data, so we want to allow as many different other stakeholders as possible to use them, which is why we also make them interactive.

So you can online, you can play with these maps to, if you're only interested in a certain mineral or a certain region, there's a lot of different purposes, but based on our Congolese mining data,  we develop what we call a responsible mining scorecards.

And that allows you as a company when you're sourcing from Congo to look per region which risk factors may exist or may not exist and how you can address them, whether it's more of a problem of, I think, of course, armed interference is a big problem, but sometimes there's other problems with illegal taxation by government services that you can maybe still find a way to deal with, or sometimes it's accident rates in artisanal mines and these kind of issues.
A lot of this work has started in the  context of a law that was introduced in the US, the Dodd-Frank Act that had certain obligations for companies to report when they were sourcing from Congo.
So the US has always been a big sponsor of this work to make sure companies have a better access to data on artisanal mining sites.
These services are something that you provide to dealers and retailers in, I guess, all different materials that were going to jury and other products.
Now, also, rather than one, it's difficult to identify one specific supply chain of one  single company because traceability doesn't exist today to be able to do that.
So we try to inform also these multi-stakeholder networks a lot.
There's the PPA on the level of the US, the Public Private Alliance for Responsible Minerals, and you have the EPRM, which is the European counterpart of that.

Mainly to also assess the impact of due diligence effort or traceability schemes that have been developed for minerals like the tree tea minerals in Congo or gold and due diligence schemes to see whether the policies of  governments and companies are adapted to these realities that exist.

One of the conclusions we, for instance, have for now based on this huge pile of data is that two diligence schemes for gold and treaty, for instance, Eastern Congo have managed to develop cleaner supply chains in a way to identify where you can source from and follow that flow.
There are some problems of contamination always.
It's hard to counter that.
But I think the downside has been they have not managed  to change conditions on the ground.
So they basically chose areas where it's safe to work from, but this does not have an impact on the broader security conditions in mines.
And we see, for instance, in the 15 years that we've been monitoring, the number of workers, the number of miners that work on mines where there's armed interference has overall stayed the same.

And it's always been around 60% of miners that work on a mining site where armed actors come and interfere with operations in various kinds of ways, through taxation, through pillaging,  through forced labor and so on.

So that is, I think, the problem of these schemes, that they have probably been too consumer oriented to ensure consumers that conditions within one supply chain are okay, but they have insufficiently focused at how can we deal with the problems that still exist.
